content: How can I help you today?

I’ve just been really struggling to sleep lately. My mind won’t stop racing at night, and I feel like there’s so much pressure at work, like I could lose my job any day. It’s hard not to worry about how I’ll support my family if that happens.

That sounds overwhelming—trying to sleep while carrying so much worry about your job and family must be tough. It seems like the stress is making it hard for your mind to slow down at night. How have you dealt with moments like this before?

Honestly, I don’t know if I’ve ever dealt with this level of stress before. Usually, I just try to power through things, but it feels different this time. I can’t seem to distract myself or calm down enough to rest.

It sounds like powering through has been a trusted approach for you in the past, but this time, it feels like the stress is stronger and harder to manage. Managing sleep while feeling this way can be really tough. What do you think might ease the pressure, even slightly, right now?

I'm not sure, honestly. I’ve tried distracting myself with TV or my phone, but that doesn’t really help. I guess if I felt more secure about my job or had a way to let go of the racing thoughts, it might take some pressure off. But I don’t know how to get there.

It sounds like security in your job and finding a way to quiet your mind could make a big difference for you. Not knowing how to get there can definitely feel discouraging, but it’s good that you’re recognizing what might help. What do you think has made your job feel less secure lately?

It’s mostly the way things have been at work lately. The stock market’s been bad, and I know layoffs could be coming. I just have this gut feeling that I’d be one of the first ones to go, and I can’t stop thinking about what that would mean for my family. It’s hard to focus on anything else.

That fear of losing your job and not being able to provide for your family feels consuming, especially with the uncertainty around layoffs. It’s understandable that it’s making it hard to focus or rest. What does supporting your family mean to you, and how does that connect to the pressure you’re feeling right now?

Supporting my family means everything to me. It means making sure my kids have what they need, keeping a roof over their heads, and making sure they feel safe and secure. The pressure comes from worrying I might not be able to do that if I lose my job—because without it, I don’t know how I’d make ends meet. That thought just keeps me up at night.

It's clear how deeply you care about your family and their well-being—that sense of responsibility sounds like both a powerful motivator and a heavy burden when uncertainties arise. Being awake at night with these thoughts must feel exhausting. What might help you feel a little more grounded or supported as you navigate through this worry?

I’m not really sure. I mean, I’m here right now because my partner wanted me to try therapy, so maybe that’s a start? But other than that, I really don’t know what would make me feel less stressed or worried about all of this right now.

It sounds like your partner’s encouragement brought you here, and that’s a meaningful step toward finding support. Even though you’re unsure of what comes next, giving yourself the space to talk about it can really help you start exploring what might ease some of the stress. If you’re open to it, we can keep talking and find small ways to help you take care of yourself during this time. Would that work for you?
Sure, let's keep talking. Maybe it'll help me figure out where to even start with all this.

That’s a thoughtful approach—to take things step by step and give yourself space to sort through it all. Sometimes talking things out can bring a bit of clarity over time. What’s something small you’d like to focus on right now? Maybe something that feels manageable amidst the bigger worries?

I guess I’d like to figure out how to quiet my mind at night. If I could at least get some sleep, maybe I’d feel better equipped to handle everything else. It’s hard to think straight when I’m this tired.

It makes sense that sleep feels like the foundation—being well-rested can make it easier to think clearly and navigate tough situations. Focusing on calming your mind at night sounds like a good place to start. Have there been any strategies or activities, in the past or recent times, that have helped you feel even a little bit calmer or more settled before bed?
Take your time—there’s no rush to figure it all out. What’s coming to mind for you as you think about ways to calm yourself before bed?
Sorry, I don't think I can do this.

That’s okay—it’s normal to feel unsure or hesitant when exploring something new like this. If talking feels overwhelming right now, it’s alright to take a pause. This space is here whenever you feel ready, and remember, your efforts to show up today are meaningful. If there’s anything else you’d like to share or focus on, that’s completely up to you.
